Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 04:28AM curlieqs wrote: I have a "Port-A-Cath II Fluoro-free" port. It is a low profile port and about the size of a penny, so it is not as noticable as the other ones. I will admit it was driving me crazy for the first 2 months, I kept "feeling" it and I wanted to dig it out, but now I hardly notice that it is there. Also, get some EMLA cream to rub on it about 1 hr before it is accessed so it will not hurt as bad. I know it must have been a hard decision to make, but it is nice to have.........your veins will thank you, lol! Best wishes!

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2008 02:40AM - edited Dec 12, 2008 02:42AM by curlieqs Oh Tania, I am so sorry. I am the same age as you :( My only advice is not to look too hard into stats. Everyone is different, and take it one day at a time. I believe that the mind is a powerful thing, and having a positive attitude can actually help with the prognosis as well as faith and a strong support system. Some may laugh at this, for I have been ridiculed by this response before. It is just my opinion. My cousin is a specialist in breast cancer, and she confirms that her patients who have a positive attitude outlive those who do not. I know it is hard to digest the news you just received, but digesting it is a process, so hang in there. I am reading this fantastic book called : Love, Medicine, and Miracles by Bernie S. Siegel M.D. It gives me great hope, and I hope you pick up a copy. May it give you hope as well. Without hope, what else is left? Hugs to you, and know that I will be thinking about you. I will keep you in my prayers. Oh, I would be more than happy to send you my copy of the book if you are interested. Just PM me. Good vibes with you for your chemo on Monday!

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2008 08:25PM curlieqs wrote: I lost alot of weight as well, I am 5'6 and was 132# and currently 120#. I agree with the Megace and what LuAnn says with the smoothies. I never tried Megace though but heard wonderful stories about it. The citrus made me sick so what I do is make ice cream shakes and I throw in a bottle of Ensure, powdered milk, and protein powder. It sits well in my belly. Drink a little at a time and throw it back in the freezer so it is all ready to go when you need it. I also take a Zofran like 1/2 hr before I eat anything. I hope this helps. Best of luck to you and hugs to you Stephanie

Posts.Title: GOOD BLOODWORK BUT STILL MAJOR PROGRESSION..HOW ? Godsgal LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2009 09:56PM - edited Feb 27, 2009 09:56PM by curlieqs Hi priz! I was in the sept chemo clan with you.....then one thing lead to another......stage IV. anyway....nice to see you again! Remember me??? It will take a few weeks to get back into the groove of things for sure. Chemo knocks the crap out of you while working!!!  I do 12 hr shift (still on chemo) and my trick is stick to a sleeping schedule. I work nocs and I find if I budge from my AT LEAST 9 HOURS of sleep, I am toast. Also, drink tons of water on shift. I know this seems impossible to us nurses who never even have time to pee, but I feel it is so crucial, and I swear, it helps me. I feel more energized when I do. No iso patients is good idea, you do not need any help with an altered immune system! I have that restriction too and almost "feel bad" for not taking the MRSA/Flu/ESBl etc, but I work with such great people they never think twice about it. Just call on your co workers to help you if necessay. You would do the same for them. Your bod has been through so much, it will just take time. I have been back since mid January, and it took until beginning of Feb to feel somewhat normal again. You will get your act together, it just takes time Good luck girl, and do not work too hard!! Hugs

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2008 05:29AM curlieqs wrote: Thanks to all who have responded to my question. I wanted to give and update. I saw the doc last week and he wants to wait until Jan 09' to do another CT of my chest. He states, "you had enough CT's this month". My tumor markers are still dropping (YAY!) and the chest pain and shortness of breath has disappeared. Could be another reason he wants to wait. BUT, I am worried that if it is lung mets, I am sure it would change my chemo regime. I am currently on Taxol, Avastin, and Zometa. Can I ask what you ladies are taking for lung mets? I am just worried that if it is mets.....here we go again "waiting"......hence my current stage IV status, because I was "waiting"!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Thanks, and hugs to you all!!!
